Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Next-Generation Microbial Fuel Cell for Highly Efficient Wastewater Treatment
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project, if successful, will be to advance the development of a novel microbial fuel cell (MFC) system that generates energy from the wastewaters being treated and that could significantly benefit wastewater treatment for a range of key industries. If successfully developed, the company's new MFC technology is expected to offer significant economic/technical advantages for these companies by reducing their disposal costs and waste volumes, reducing the footprint of treatment facilities, and helping them to adopt a more-sustainable process for wastewater treatment. Treatment of organic-rich wastewater is energy-intensive, consuming 15 GigaWatts (GW) or 3% of all electrical power produced in the United States. However, this water contains roughly 17 GW of potential energy. Capturing a portion of this energy through MFC technology would favorably reduce wastewater treatment energy requirements leading to a more economical treatment process.

The objectives of this Phase I research project are to demonstrate the scalability of the company's proprietary, low-cost MFC cathode material, its long-term performance, and the feasibility of the company's MFC design to effectively clean beverage wastewater. The need to maintain MFC reactor performance during scale-up and to reduce cathode cost is a major technical challenge for using MFC for wastewater treatment. The successful completion of the proposed research will result in the translation of the laboratory cathode fabrication recipe to a larger-scale manufacturing procedure. Integration of the low-cost cathode material and the unique MFC modular design is expected to provide breakthrough performance and cost that will enable the broad-based economically viable and modular commercial deployment of an MFC wastewater treatment process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Growing concern over the substantial energy requirements needed for wastewater treatment and the impact of fossil fuel usage on climate change have stimulated interest in energy neutral wastewater treatment technologies.  One promising approach is the microbial fuel cell (MFC) technology, which generates electricity directly from the wastewaters being treated.  Such a system could revolutionize the treatment of energy-rich wastewater. The need to maintain MFC reactor performance during scale-up and to reduce cathode cost is a major technical challenge for using MFC for wastewater treatment. With the support of this NSF STTR Phase I, the company and its collaborating institution significantly advanced the state-of-the-art in MFC technology for wastewater treatment and electricity generation.  The Phase I project demonstrated the scalability of their proprietary, low-cost MFC cathode material and the technical and economic feasibility of the company’s MFC system to effectively clean brewery and fruit processing wastewaters. A cubic meter MFC was successfully fabricated and tested at a brewery and a fruit processing plant. Onsite testing demonstrated that the scaled-up MFC can produce 100x more power than other MFCs of similar size, while achieving much faster pollution removal. Utilizing this technology, over 80% savings in wastewater surcharges is expected for both breweries and fruit processors. The successful Phase I project has established the feasibility of the innovation and provides justification for further NSF support in Phase II and commercial applications. 

Besides the brewery and fruit processing industries, the newly developed MFC system may provide a viable solution for the treatment of domestic wastewater and many other industrial wastewaters. The novel electrode materials and the reactor design may also be used for manufacturing other microbial electrochemical systems for a wide range of different applications, such as remote sensing, portable power supplies, and microbial electrosynthesis. The project trained both undergraduate and graduate students, including a female student in Engineering.

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2016
Modified by: Yanzhen Fan
